study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the dietary preferences of young people with IBD and evaluate the impact of Mediterranean Diet-focused culinary medicine classes on adherence and dietary habits.
results_summary: The study found that Mediterranean Diet adherence scores improved post-intervention (from a median of 4.5 at baseline to 7.0 at 3 months), with high participant interest in dietary management and positive reception of cooking classes. Common barriers included lack of knowledge about food preparation, taste concerns, and time constraints.
population_specificity: Young people (ages 6-17) with inflammatory bowel disease (IBD), including Crohn's disease, ulcerative colitis, and IBD unclassified.
study_duration: 3 months (with follow-up surveys at 1 and 3 months post-intervention)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining yoga with a Mediterranean diet could improve health outcomes in older adults.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in nutritional status, balance, gait, flexibility, and muscle strength in the experimental group compared to the control group. Effect sizes ranged from small to moderate, with the largest improvements seen in lower body strength and left arm flexibility.
population_specificity: Community-dwelling older adults (n = 116, aged not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a structured Mediterranean diet intervention on the cortical structure of the maternal brain during pregnancy.
results_summary: The Mediterranean diet group showed significantly larger surface areas in the right precuneus and left superior parietal lobules compared to the usual care group. These structural changes were associated with improved adherence to the diet, high walnut intake, and high urinary hydroxytyrosol concentrations.
population_specificity: High-risk pregnant women (n = 71 analyzed, subset of 1221 from the IMPACT BCN trial).
study_duration: Intervention administered from 19-23 weeks of gestation until the third trimester.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) supplements with a multicomponent health promotion and physical exercise programme could improve disease activity, clinical characteristics, cardiovascular risk, and molecular markers in systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) patients.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific results, as the study is prospective and outcomes will be assessed pre-, mid-, and post-intervention.
population_specificity: Patients with systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the benefits of the Mediterranean diet, barriers to adherence in the US (especially among racial/ethnic minorities), and provide recommendations for improving adherence and cultural adaptations.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to the Mediterranean diet lowers the risk of chronic diseases (cardiovascular, neurodegenerative, cancer), improves depression, aids weight loss, and reduces adverse pregnancy outcomes. However, research on barriers and adherence among US racial/ethnic minorities, particularly Native American and Alaskan Native populations, is lacking.
population_specificity: Mediterranean and non-Mediterranean countries, with a focus on racial and ethnic minority populations in the US.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of nutritional interventions, including the Mediterranean diet, to modulate cardiotoxicity in breast cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy.
results_summary: One study focused on nutritional counselling and adherence to the Mediterranean diet in breast cancer survivors post-treatment, showing significant improvements in cardiac biomarkers and attenuated reduction in LVEF. The Mediterranean diet was associated with positive cardiometabolic outcomes.
population_specificity: Breast cancer survivors post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of the Mediterranean Diet (MeDi) in mitigating the effects of environmental pollutants on Alzheimer's disease (AD) by reducing oxidative stress, inflammation, and improving gut microbiota.
results_summary: The study found that the Mediterranean Diet, along with other specific diets like DASH and MIND, helps decrease oxidative stress and inflammation, supports neuronal growth, and positively alters gut microbiota, thereby reducing pollutant-induced inflammation and potentially slowing AD progression.
population_specificity: Populations with high exposure to environmental pollutants, particularly those at risk for neurodegenerative disorders like Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize current literature on the potential role of the Mediterranean diet in managing hidradenitis suppurativa (HS).
results_summary: The abstract suggests that the Mediterranean diet, among other dietary interventions, has shown promise in individual cases and observational studies for HS management, but definitive links remain unclear due to limited controlled prospective studies.
population_specificity: Individuals with hidradenitis suppurativa (HS).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the Mediterranean diet on ageing and age-related diseases, comparing it with other dietary patterns for longevity and health span.
results_summary: The study found that the Mediterranean diet has potential benefits for promoting healthy ageing and mitigating age-related diseases such as cardiovascular disease, cancer, neurodegenerative disorders, and metabolic syndrome, due to its distinct nutritional profile and bioactive components.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population inferred)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects and mechanisms of the Mediterranean Diet (MD) on breast cancer (BC) incidence, recurrence, and prevention, including its components and genetic interactions.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to the MD is associated with reduced BC risk and improved prognosis, with variations based on menopausal status and BC type. It also highlighted the role of individual MD components, vitamins, and exercise in BC prevention and recurrence.
population_specificity: Healthy women of various ages and breast cancer patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether a Mediterranean diet-inspired oral nutritional supplement (with or without probiotics) could alter miRNA expression and target genes in malnourished hemodialysis patients compared to standard dietary recommendations.
results_summary: The study found that the Mediterranean diet-inspired supplement improved caloric-protein intake, nutritional status, and biomarkers of inflammation and oxidation in malnourished hemodialysis patients, though miRNA-related outcomes were not detailed in the abstract.
population_specificity: Malnourished or at-risk hemodialysis patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).

study_goal: To compare the effects of the Mediterranean diet combined with hypercaloric, hyperproteic oral supplements in patients with heart failure.
results_summary: The study found that nutritional support, including the Mediterranean diet, was associated with decreased NT-proBNP levels, improved left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), functionality, and quality of life, along with reduced hospital admissions.
population_specificity: Patients with heart failure (38 participants).
effective_dosage: Not specified for the Mediterranean diet; hypercaloric, hyperproteic oral supplements were used in the intervention group.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of olive tree polyphenols, a component of the Mediterranean diet, as a natural remedy to inhibit SARS-CoV-2 by affecting viral entry into host cells.
results_summary: The study suggests that polyphenols from olive leaves may have anti-inflammatory and antiviral effects, potentially benefiting COVID-19 patients by inhibiting viral entry. The Mediterranean diet's polyphenols were highlighted for their multitarget antiviral properties.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients (general, no specific subgroup mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of olive tree polyphenols, a component of the Mediterranean diet, as a co-therapy supplement for treating COVID-19 symptoms and preventing SARS-CoV-2 infection.
results_summary: The study suggests that olive tree polyphenols, such as oleuropein and hydroxytyrosol, have anti-inflammatory and antiviral effects that may contribute to the Mediterranean diet's benefits against COVID-19, though more research is needed.
population_specificity: COVID-19 patients (inferred, not explicitly stated)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of seaweed consumption, as part of dietary interventions like the Mediterranean diet, on diabetes management metrics such as blood glucose, HbA1c, and insulin resistance.
results_summary: The study found significant improvements in postprandial blood glucose, HbA1c, and HOMA-IR levels with seaweed consumption, but no significant effects on fasting blood glucose or insulin levels. High-dose seaweed (1000 mg or more) showed greater benefits than low-dose.
population_specificity: Individuals with diabetes or at risk of diabetes (specific population not detailed in abstract).
effective_dosage: High dose (1000 mg or more) of seaweed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the role of non-pharmacological interventions, including the Mediterranean diet, in managing endocrine-related infertility in women.
results_summary: The study highlighted the Mediterranean diet as part of a non-pharmacological approach to improving fertility, alongside vitamin supplementation, exercise, and weight management, but did not provide specific efficacy data for the diet alone.
population_specificity: Women with endocrine-related infertility.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of a dietary supplement containing 2.5 g of phytosterols on lipid profiles in individuals with polygenic hypercholesterolemia, also considering diet quality.
results_summary: The study found that dietary supplementation with phytosterols significantly improved plasma levels of total cholesterol (-11.8 ± 4.0 mg/dL). The results suggest a beneficial effect on lipid profiles in the studied population.
population_specificity: 50 Italian individuals with polygenic hypercholesterolemia and low global cardiovascular risk.
effective_dosage: 2.5 g of phytosterols, once-a-day ready-to-drink supplement.
study_duration: 3-week treatment periods with a 2-week washout in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate nutritional strategies, including Mediterranean Diet, for improving knee osteoarthritis clinical severity and sarcopenic obesity indices.
results_summary: The study found that adherence to a Mediterranean Diet, combined with low-calorie diets, is a cornerstone nutritional treatment for improving knee osteoarthritis and sarcopenic obesity. Supplementation with micronutrients like vitamin D and whey protein also showed benefits.
population_specificity: Individuals with knee osteoarthritis and sarcopenic obesity, particularly those with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of the Mediterranean diet, along with other nutritional interventions, in preserving endothelial glycocalyx (eGC) health and preventing cardiovascular diseases.
results_summary: The study suggests that the Mediterranean diet, along with vitamin D and omega-3 fatty acid supplementation, may help preserve eGC health, thereby supporting cardiovascular health. However, the relationship between diet, lifestyle, and eGC preservation remains largely unexplored.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, no specific population studied)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of healthy lifestyle strategies, including the Mediterranean diet, on managing insulin resistance and related metabolic derangements in pediatric obesity.
results_summary: The study found that adopting the Mediterranean diet is a useful dietary approach for glucose metabolism control, though long-term impacts of varying macronutrients on cardiometabolic risk remain unclear.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the evidence on the effect of Mediterranean Diet adherence on disease activity in axial spondyloarthritis (axSpA).
results_summary: One observational study found an association between Mediterranean Diet adherence and a ≥20% decrease in ASDAS (a disease activity measure) in axSpA. Other dietary interventions showed mixed or poor-quality results.
population_specificity: Adult patients with axial spondyloarthritis (axSpA).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential of extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) supplementation in delaying or preventing sarcopenia by examining its anti-inflammatory and antioxidative properties.
results_summary: The abstract suggests EVOO may help attenuate muscle wasting in aging individuals, but the molecular mechanisms remain undefined, and further research is needed to confirm its efficacy.
population_specificity: Aging individuals with or at risk of sarcopenia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if supplementing the Mediterranean Diet with mixed apple and bergamot juice (MAB juice) for 2 weeks improved body composition, biochemical profile, and oxidative/inflammatory gene expression compared to the Mediterranean Diet alone.
results_summary: The study found that adding MAB juice to the Mediterranean Diet led to increased lean mass, reduced total cholesterol/HDL index, and upregulated gene expressions related to oxidative and inflammatory pathways (MIF, PPARγ, SOD1, VDR), suggesting a potential reduction in chronic disease risk.
population_specificity: 24 subjects (specific demographics not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the role of the Mediterranean diet in glycemic control for pregnant women with GDM affected by COVID-19.
results_summary: The study suggests that the Mediterranean diet, along with micronutrient supplementation and physical activity, is considered a first-line treatment for achieving glycemic control in pregnant women with GDM and COVID-19, potentially reducing adverse outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women with gestational diabetes mellitus (GDM) affected by COVID-19, particularly those with overweight or obesity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the impact of different nutritional plans, including the Mediterranean Diet, on the course of ulcerative colitis (UC).
results_summary: The Mediterranean Diet showed promising results in treating UC due to its high content of biologically active foods, positively influencing gut microbiome composition and function. However, evidence for other dietary interventions like omega-3 fatty acids and probiotics was not unequivocal.
population_specificity: Patients with ulcerative colitis (UC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of dietary patterns, particularly the Mediterranean diet, on risk biomarkers in individuals with familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).
results_summary: The Mediterranean diet showed more robust effects on plasma LDL-C, apolipoprotein B, and C-reactive protein concentrations compared to diets restricted in saturated fatty acids. However, most studies were limited by cross-sectional design, small sample sizes, and short-term follow-ups.
population_specificity: Individuals with familial hypercholesterolemia (FH).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the potential role of the Mediterranean diet in preventing COVID-19 infection and severe illness.
results_summary: The study found mixed and inconsistent evidence regarding the efficacy of the Mediterranean diet in reducing infection risk, disease duration, severity, and recovery from COVID-19. More clinical trials are needed to establish clear benefits.
population_specificity: Not specified (general discussion, no specific population studied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the molecular effects of single nutrients, particularly those in the Mediterranean diet, on sperm quality and their involvement in biochemical mechanisms related to sperm bioenergetics.
results_summary: The study found that diets rich in saturated fatty acids negatively affect sperm quality, while unsaturated fatty acids, especially omega-3 PUFA, improve mitochondrial energetic metabolism and reduce oxidative damage. Carbohydrates, proteins, and dietary polyphenols also modulate oxidative stress and testosterone levels, which are linked to sperm mitochondrial function.
population_specificity: Males, focusing on reproductive potential and sperm quality.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of a Mediterranean diet and/or omega-3 supplementation on impulsive behavior in children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplementation led to a significant decrease in impulsiveness, while the Mediterranean diet showed modest improvements in BIS scores, though results were not conclusive. Total nonplanning scores improved across all groups.
population_specificity: 60 children with ADHD from Madrid, Spain.
effective_dosage: 550 mg EPA and 225 mg DHA per day (for omega-3 supplementation group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether a modified Mediterranean diet (mMeD) could improve dietary inflammatory status, disability, and fatigue severity in relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) patients compared to a traditional Iranian diet (TID).
results_summary: The study found that adherence to mMeD for 6 months improved dietary inflammatory status and fatigue severity in RRMS patients, while the TID did not show positive effects on dietary inflammation or fatigue.
population_specificity: Relapsing-remitting multiple sclerosis (RRMS) patients (n=147).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize current understanding of dietary influences on frailty, focusing on the potential of the Mediterranean diet for prevention and treatment.
results_summary: Observational evidence suggests the Mediterranean diet is protective against frailty, with healthier dietary profiles linked to lower frailty risk. Few intervention studies exist, but multi-domain approaches combining diet and exercise may be more effective.
population_specificity: Global ageing population, particularly those at risk of frailty.

study_goal: To determine whether a Mediterranean Diet (MedDiet) compared to nut consumption in a non-MedDiet context has a greater beneficial effect on gut microbiota and fecal metabolites, potentially explaining improvements in cardiometabolic risk factors.
results_summary: Following a MedDiet significantly increased Lachnospiraceae NK4A136 and improved metabolic risk, potentially through effects on bile acid metabolism and cadaverine, leading to better insulin levels.
population_specificity: Fifty adults with Metabolic Syndrome.
effective_dosage: Nuts (50 g/day) in the non-MedDiet group; MedDiet specifics not detailed.
study_duration: 2 months per intervention with a 1-month wash-out period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a polyphenol-rich supplement within the Mediterranean diet could improve health-related quality of life (HRQOL) in overweight and obese individuals.
results_summary: After 16 weeks, supplemented individuals experienced a significant improvement in HRQOL (+5.3%), despite no adherence to the Mediterranean Diet Serving Score (MDSS). Body composition and physical activity were monitored, but no specific dietary adherence was noted.
population_specificity: Overweight and obese but otherwise healthy individuals (72 volunteers).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate how dietary patterns, including the Mediterranean Diet, influence gut microbiome composition and its potential impact on immunotherapy efficacy in cancer treatment.
results_summary: The study found that the Mediterranean Diet alters gut microbiome composition, which may modulate immune system function and enhance anti-cancer response. Specific gut bacteria species were linked to improved immunotherapy efficacy, while antibiotics negatively affected treatment outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with various types of cancer undergoing immunotherapy.
interactions: Antibiotics weakened gut bacteria and reduced immunotherapy efficacy, while probiotics and fecal microbiota transplants showed potential benefits. Other factors like vitamins, glucose, and BMI also influenced treatment response.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Mediterranean Diet adherence, specific nutrients, or supplementation could improve symptoms, delay onset, or accelerate onset in Huntington's disease patients.
results_summary: High/moderate adherence to the Mediterranean Diet showed slight improvements in cognitive and motor scores, quality of life, and disease rating scales, but findings were inconsistent. Specific nutrient supplements like triheaptanoin, L-acetyl-carnitine, and creatine showed no beneficial effects.
population_specificity: People with Huntington's disease (HD)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of the Mediterranean Diet (MedDiet) compared to nuts supplementation on circulating metabolites and their relationship with cardiometabolic health, as well as the interplay between diet, metabolites, and gut microbiota.
results_summary: The MedDiet was associated with significant changes in 65 circulating metabolites, including lipids, acylcarnitines, and amino acids, which correlated with improvements in glucose, insulin, and HOMA-IR. The study also identified a network linking specific gut bacteria to these metabolic changes.
population_specificity: 44 adults aged 37-65 with Metabolic Syndrome (MetS)
effective_dosage: Non-MedDiet plus 50 g/day of nuts (comparator group)

study_goal: To evaluate the effects of nutrition, particularly the Mediterranean Diet, during the COVID-19 pandemic in both hospitalized patients and the general population.
results_summary: The study found that a Mediterranean Diet, along with supplementation of micronutrients and vitamins, may be beneficial for preventing or improving prognosis in SARS-CoV-2 infection. Six studies focused on nutritional interventions for SARS-CoV-2 patients, while others highlighted potential benefits of the Mediterranean Diet.
population_specificity: Hospitalized patients with SARS-CoV-2 infection and the general population.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the characteristics and clinical applications of extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) and its components in clinical nutrition and dietetics, focusing on its therapeutic potential.
results_summary: The study found that EVOO has diverse beneficial health properties, supporting its use in diet therapy and supplementation to improve cardiovascular health, lipoprotein metabolism, and diabetes mellitus. However, more human intervention studies are needed for specific recommendations.
population_specificity: Clinical nutrition and dietetics populations, including those with cardiovascular and metabolic conditions.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential cardiovascular benefits of hydroxytyrosol, a polyphenolic compound in olive oil, through its antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, and anti-atherogenic effects.
results_summary: Hydroxytyrosol demonstrated strong antioxidant properties, reduced inflammation and oxidative stress, and improved lipid profiles in both healthy subjects and metabolic syndrome patients. These effects suggest potential therapeutic benefits for cardiovascular disease prevention and treatment.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and metabolic syndrome patients.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the health impact of a low-inflammatory diet (or supplement) compared to usual diets on weight change, inflammatory biomarkers, joint symptoms, and quality of life in adults with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that low-inflammatory diets were associated with greater weight loss and improvement in inflammatory biomarkers, but no significant effects were observed for physical function, general health, or joint pain. The evidence quality was rated as very low.
population_specificity: Adults with osteoarthritis or rheumatoid arthritis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of the Mediterranean diet on reducing the risk of gestational diabetes and its effects on placental inflammation and nutrient transport.
results_summary: The Mediterranean diet was found to reduce the risk of gestational diabetes in a multicenter randomized trial, suggesting its potential role in improving maternal and fetal health outcomes.
population_specificity: Pregnant women, particularly those at risk of gestational diabetes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the impact of the Mediterranean diet and omega-3 supplementation on impulsive behavior in children with ADHD.
results_summary: The study found that omega-3 supplementation led to a significant decrease in impulsiveness (BIS-11c scores), while the Mediterranean diet showed modest improvements in cognitive scores. The combined intervention (diet + omega-3) did not conclusively outperform individual treatments.
population_specificity: 60 children with ADHD from Madrid, Spain.
effective_dosage: 550mg EPA and 225mg DHA per day (omega-3 supplementation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the associations of the Mediterranean, DASH, and MIND diets with cognitive decline, dementia, and Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the Mediterranean diet was associated with better cognitive scores in most studies and a lower risk of Alzheimer's disease, with the strongest associations observed for the MIND diet.
population_specificity: General population, with a focus on cognitive decline and dementia risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of the Mediterranean Diet (MeDiet) in protecting against cognitive decline and neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's.
results_summary: The study found that MeDiet, along with nutritional support and calorie-controlled diets, has a protective effect against cognitive decline, Alzheimer's disease, and Parkinson's disease, while malnutrition and insulin resistance are significant risk factors. Omega-3, omega-6, and vitamin supplementation were less effective in protecting against neuron degeneration.
population_specificity: Individuals at risk of or experiencing cognitive impairment and neurodegenerative diseases.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to confirm the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a calorie-restricted Mediterranean diet with targeted dietary supplementation (PROG2) in overweight and obese subjects with cardiometabolic risk factors.
results_summary: The diet was well tolerated with 86% compliance, and common adverse effects (bloating, flatulence, constipation) were self-limiting. Subjects exhibited decreases in key cardiometabolic metrics, suggesting positive effects.
population_specificity: Fifty healthy overweight and obese subjects with cardiometabolic risk factors.
effective_dosage: ∼68-76% of estimated calorie requirements, including protein shakes and targeted supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify potential targets (food patterns, single foods, or individual nutrients) for preventing CVD and quantify the magnitude of the beneficial effects of the Mediterranean Diet.
results_summary: The study found that the Mediterranean Diet leads to better inflammatory cytokine balance compared to Western dietary patterns and shows greater beneficial effects than single nutrient supplementation for CVD prevention.
population_specificity: Not specified (general Western population implied).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the hypothesis that hyperphosphatemia may mediate the association between low vitamin D levels and increased cancer risk, and to challenge the UVB-vitamin D-cancer hypothesis by proposing dietary phosphate intake (as in the Mediterranean diet) as a potential factor in reduced cancer risk at lower latitudes.
results_summary: The study suggests that reduced dietary phosphate intake, such as in the Mediterranean diet, may lower cancer risk by mitigating hyperphosphatemia, which is linked to tumorigenesis. It challenges the UVB-vitamin D-cancer hypothesis, proposing instead that soil and dietary phosphate differences in tropical regions may explain lower cancer incidence.
population_specificity: Not specified (theoretical/mini-review)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Mediterranean diet modifies the association between long-term air pollution exposure and cardiovascular disease mortality risk.
results_summary: The study found that a Mediterranean diet reduced cardiovascular disease mortality risk related to long-term exposure to air pollutants, with significant associations observed for fine particulate matter and nitrogen dioxide. Increased consumption of antioxidant-rich foods was suggested to mitigate the disease burden from air pollution.
population_specificity: A prospective cohort of 548,845 participants across 6 states and 2 cities in the United States.
effective_dosage: Not specified (assessed via the 9-point alternative Mediterranean Diet Index).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a Mediterranean-like dietary pattern (NU-AGE diet) tailored for older adults could effectively shift dietary intake toward a healthier diet and reduce inflammaging.
results_summary: The NU-AGE diet group improved intake of 13 out of 16 dietary components, suggesting the intervention was effective in promoting healthier dietary habits among older adults. The study concluded that the NU-AGE diet may be a feasible strategy to improve dietary intake in aging populations.
population_specificity: Adults aged 65–80 years across five EU centers.
effective_dosage: Consumption of 15 food groups plus a vitamin D supplement (specific dosage not mentioned).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of a plant extract-based supplement on oxidative stress markers in overweight individuals with medium adherence to the Mediterranean Diet.
results_summary: The supplement significantly reduced DNA/RNA damage and protein carbonyls by approximately 30% and 20%, respectively, and showed resistance to urine isoprostanes, but no significant changes were observed in oxidized LDL or serum resistance to oxidation.
population_specificity: Overweight, apparently healthy volunteers with medium adherence to the Mediterranean Diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the role of nutrition, including the Mediterranean Diet, in aging, frailty risk, and potential interventions for frail or pre-frail patients.
results_summary: The study found that promoting a Mediterranean Diet is beneficial for frail patients, alongside adequate protein intake and Vitamin D supplementation, as it helps mitigate frailty risks and consequences.
population_specificity: Frail and pre-frail patients, particularly older adults at risk of malnutrition.
effective_dosage: Not specified for Mediterranean Diet; protein intake recommended at 1-1.2 g per kg of body weight per day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding standardized tomato extract (STE) or acetylsalicylic acid (ASA) to standard antihypertensive therapy improves blood pressure control in high-risk hypertensive patients.
results_summary: The study found that STE significantly reduced 24-hour systolic BP, diastolic BP, mean arterial pressure, and pulse pressure, particularly in obese patients, while ASA showed no significant BP reduction. The results suggest STE may have pleiotropic effects beneficial for hypertensive patients with high cardiovascular risk.
population_specificity: 82 high-risk hypertensive patients with primary hypertension at high to very high total cardiovascular risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the cardioprotective properties of the Mediterranean Diet, particularly focusing on the role of extra virgin olive oil (EVOO) in reducing cardiovascular events.
results_summary: The study found that EVOO, a key component of the Mediterranean Diet, exhibits anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, and vasodilatory effects, which may lower atherosclerotic burden and reduce the incidence of cardiovascular events like myocardial infarction and stroke. Epidemiological and intervention studies support these findings.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects and individuals at cardiovascular risk.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether oral supplementation with extra virgin olive oil enriched with vitamins D could improve platelet function and reduce nitrosative stress in postmenopausal women.
results_summary: The study found that women taking the enriched olive oil showed lower nitric oxide and peroxynitrite levels, improved platelet membrane fluidity, and reduced oxidative stress markers compared to the placebo group. These results suggest a potential antioxidant benefit of the supplement.
population_specificity: Postmenopausal women (n=60)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a Mediterranean diet, with or without antioxidant supplementation, on overweight patients with NAFLD.
results_summary: The Mediterranean diet alone or combined with antioxidants improved anthropometric parameters, lipid profile, and reduced hepatic fat accumulation and liver stiffness. The diet with antioxidants also significantly improved insulin sensitivity and showed greater reductions in anthropometric parameters compared to diet alone.
population_specificity: Overweight Caucasian patients with NAFLD.
effective_dosage: Not specified (antioxidant complex supplement was administered daily).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between adherence to the Mediterranean diet at midlife and healthy aging, defined by multiple health dimensions.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the Mediterranean diet was associated with increased odds of healthy aging, with potential mediation by metabolic health-related factors.
population_specificity: 3,012 French adults aged 45-60 years at baseline, initially free of major chronic diseases.
effective_dosage: Not specified (adherence assessed via dietary records).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adherence to the Mediterranean Diet was associated with a reduced risk of incident depressive symptoms in a large French cohort.
results_summary: Higher adherence to the Mediterranean Diet was significantly associated with a lower risk of depressive symptoms in men but not in women, with similar findings across different dietary scoring methods.
population_specificity: 3523 participants from the French SU.VI.MAX cohort, initially free of depression.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the influence of nutritional factors, particularly the Mediterranean diet, on cognitive frailty and its potential mediators.
results_summary: The study found that combining various dietary and lifestyle components in the Mediterranean dietary pattern showed benefits in preventing cognitive decline and physical frailty, though no single food or supplement definitively demonstrated efficacy. A lifelong balanced Mediterranean diet, combined with regular physical and mental exercise, was highlighted as the best preventive strategy against cognitive decline in old age.
population_specificity: Older adults, particularly those at risk of cognitive frailty and physical frailty.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss food-drug interactions related to Mediterranean Diet components and their impact on drug efficacy and toxicity.
results_summary: The abstract highlights the decreased prevalence of cardiovascular diseases associated with Mediterranean Diet but also notes potential toxicological side effects and pharmacokinetic interactions when combined with synthetic drugs.
population_specificity: General population (not specified further)
interactions: Food supplement-drug interactions leading to changes in absorption, distribution, metabolism, and excretion processes.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of Mediterranean Diet, particularly omega-3 fatty acids, on improving Aβ phagocytosis and regulating inflammatory genes in MCI and AD patients.
results_summary: Omega-3 fatty acids increased resolvin D1, improved Aβ phagocytosis, and regulated inflammatory genes toward a physiological state, but only in MCI patients. The study also identified adherence to Mediterranean Diet with omega-3 and exercise as positive factors.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD) and minor cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the interaction of genetics with cardiovascular risk factors in a non-Mediterranean population with coronary artery disease (CAD) under three different diets: pecan nuts, olive oil, or a control diet.
results_summary: The study focuses on the potential benefits of diets rich in nuts and olive oil in a Brazilian population with CAD, examining changes in LDL-cholesterol and other biochemical markers. It also explores how genetic polymorphisms may modulate these effects.
population_specificity: Brazilian individuals aged 40-80 years diagnosed with coronary artery disease (CAD).
effective_dosage: Group 1: 30 g/day of pecan nuts; Group 2: 30 ml/day of olive oil; Group 3: control diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to synthesize data from randomized controlled trials to evaluate the effects of olive oil (a key component of the Mediterranean diet) on markers of inflammation and endothelial function.
results_summary: Olive oil interventions significantly reduced C-reactive protein and interleukin-6 levels and improved flow-mediated dilatation, suggesting beneficial effects on inflammation and endothelial function. However, the study notes heterogeneity in study designs, warranting cautious interpretation.
population_specificity: 3106 participants across 30 randomized controlled trials.
effective_dosage: Daily consumption ranging approximately between 1 mg and 50 mg of olive oil.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the beneficial effects of Mediterranean diet components, particularly anthocyanins, on preventing or reducing the risk of chronic degenerative diseases.
results_summary: The study found that dietary anthocyanin enrichment is beneficial against ischemic and degenerative conditions in experimental models, and human studies showed that anthocyanin supplementation can counteract inflammatory responses to stress conditions. An ongoing trial is testing its effects on inflammatory responses and skin toxicity in breast cancer patients undergoing radiotherapy.
population_specificity: Patients with breast cancer undergoing radiotherapy (ongoing trial), general human studies, and experimental models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the validity of methods for assessing non-alcoholic beverage, sodium, food supplement, and oil intake, with a focus on the Mediterranean diet's components.
results_summary: The study highlights the lack of standardized tools for evaluating intake of these dietary components and notes the benefits of olive oil in the Mediterranean diet, including its nutrient content. It also points out risks associated with high sodium consumption and the potential advantages of using biomarkers for dietary assessment.
population_specificity: General population (not specified further).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the benefit and harm of non-pharmacological interventions, including Mediterranean Diet, for managing fatigue in people with rheumatoid arthritis.
results_summary: The study found that Mediterranean diet was one of the interventions evaluated, but meta-analysis was not possible, and there was either no statistically significant difference between trial arms or findings were not reported. The quality of evidence for Mediterranean diet was rated as moderate.
population_specificity: Adults with rheumatoid arthritis (51 participants in the Mediterranean diet study).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of the Mediterranean diet in modulating Alzheimer disease (AD) and compare its effects with other nutritional interventions.
results_summary: The study found that a Mediterranean-type diet was associated with a reduced likelihood of developing AD, while B-vitamin supplements and omega-3 fatty acids showed inconsistent or negative results. Combination supplements like Souvenaid had small cognitive benefits.
population_specificity: Persons at risk of or with Alzheimer disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the impact of olive oil (OO) supplementation, either low or high in phenolics, on urinary proteomic biomarkers related to coronary artery disease (CAD), chronic kidney disease (CKD), and diabetes.
results_summary: Both low- and high-phenolic OO improved the proteomic CAD score after 6 weeks, but there was no significant difference between the two groups. No improvements were observed for CKD or diabetes biomarkers, nor for secondary outcomes like blood lipids and oxidized LDL.
population_specificity: Self-reported healthy participants (n = 69), randomized by age and BMI.
effective_dosage: 20 mL daily of either low-phenolic (18 mg caffeic acid equivalents/kg) or high-phenolic (286 mg caffeic acid equivalents/kg) OO.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of a Mediterranean-style dietary intervention, enriched with olive oil, Vitamin D, and omega-3 fatty acids, on embryo developmental competency and the intrauterine nutritional environment in couples undergoing IVF.
results_summary: The study did not report specific efficacy results in the abstract, but it was designed to measure embryo developmental competency using morphokinetic markers and assess the intrauterine nutritional environment. The abstract suggests prior retrospective studies indicated potential benefits, but prospective findings were not detailed.
population_specificity: Couples undergoing in vitro fertilization (IVF).
effective_dosage: Olive oil for cooking, olive oil-based spread, and a daily supplement with 10 µg Vitamin D and 2 g marine omega-3 fatty acids.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the prospective association between adherence to Mediterranean diet scores and the 6-year risk of MetS and its components in a large European cohort.
results_summary: Higher adherence to Mediterranean diet scores (MED and MDS) was associated with a lower risk of MetS and beneficial effects on its components, including waist circumference, blood pressure, triglycerides, and HDL-cholesterol. The study supports encouraging Mediterranean dietary patterns to reduce MetS risk.
population_specificity: Participants from the SU.VI.MAX study in Europe (n=3,232).
effective_dosage: Not specified (adherence assessed via dietary scores from at least three 24-hour records).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess and compare the predictive value of six dietary scores, including Mediterranean Diet scores, on weight change and obesity risk over 13 years in adults aged 45+.
results_summary: Higher adherence to Mediterranean Diet scores (MDS, rMED) was associated with lower weight gain in men and reduced obesity risk (ORs 0.63-0.72). Associations were weaker or non-significant in women.
population_specificity: French adults aged 45+ from the SU.VI.MAX study (n=3151).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the association between midlife Mediterranean diet adherence and cognitive performance later in life, and whether occupation and education modified this effect.
results_summary: The study found no significant association between Mediterranean diet adherence and cognitive performance, except for minor effects on phonemic fluency and backward digit span scores. A weak association was observed in manual workers, but no interaction was found with educational level.
population_specificity: 3083 middle-aged subjects from the SU.VI.MAX study.
study_duration: Dietary records were collected from 1994-1996, with cognitive assessments in 2007-2009 (13-year follow-up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of extravirgin olive oil (EVOO) and its phenolic compounds on endocannabinoid system (ECS) gene expression via epigenetic regulation in colon cancer cells and rats.
results_summary: EVOO and its phenolic compounds selectively upregulated the CNR1 gene (encoding CB₁ receptor) via reduced DNA methylation, correlating with reduced proliferation in colon cancer cells. Similar effects were observed in rats, with a 4-fold increase in CB₁ expression and reduced methylation at the Cnr1 promoter after 10 days of EVOO supplementation.
population_specificity: Human colon cancer cells (Caco-2) and rats.
effective_dosage: EVOO (100 ppm), phenolic extracts (OPE, 50 μM), hydroxytyrosol (HT, 50 μM) in vitro; dietary EVOO supplementation in rats.
study_duration: 24 hours in vitro; 10 days in vivo.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of zinc supplementation and Mediterranean Diet in addressing zinc deficiency and immune response in the elderly.
results_summary: The study found that zinc supplementation may improve immune function in elderly individuals, particularly those with specific IL-6 polymorphism (GG allele carriers), while Mediterranean Diet may suffice for the general elderly population to restore zinc deficiency and immune response.
population_specificity: Elderly individuals aged 60-65 years and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the role of nutrition, particularly dietary patterns like the Mediterranean diet, in preventing functional decline and disability in older adults.
results_summary: The study suggests that the Mediterranean diet may help prevent negative functional outcomes in older adults, though intervention studies using nutritional supplementation have shown inconclusive results in preventing functional impairment and disability.
population_specificity: Older adults transitioning from independence to disability.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of ultrasound-assisted MCT replacement of lard on emulsifying stability, adsorption behavior, and oxidative stability in myofibrillar protein emulsions.
results_summary: The study found that ultrasound-assisted MCT emulsions had superior emulsifying activity, stability, smaller particle size, and enhanced oxidative stability compared to lard emulsions. MCTs also promoted protein adsorption at the oil-water interface, leading to structural changes in myofibrillar protein.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro study on myofibrillar protein emulsions)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of Medium-chain Triglycerides (MCT) supplementation on seizure severity and associated neurobehavioral comorbidities in a pentylenetetrazole (PTZ) mouse kindling model.
results_summary: MCT supplementation significantly reduced seizure severity, reversed depression-like behavior, and attenuated altered hippocampal lipid peroxidation and mTOR/Gsk-3β signaling in kindled mice. No changes were observed in locomotion or anxiety indices.
population_specificity: PTZ-kindled mice (animal model for epilepsy).
effective_dosage: Not specified for MCT (only PTZ dosage: 35 mg/kg i.p. every other day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the Mediterranean diet, rich in antioxidants and anti-inflammatory nutrients, could contribute to skin cancer prevention by supporting internal sun-protection mechanisms.
results_summary: The study suggests that the Mediterranean diet, containing antioxidant vitamins, minerals, phytochemicals, and beneficial fatty acids, may help reduce photo-oxidative damage and lower melanoma rates, complementing external sun-protection strategies.
population_specificity: General population in the Mediterranean region (implied, not explicitly stated).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) for weight loss and glucolipid metabolism improvement in individuals with overweight and obesity, specifically comparing pure MCTs and medium-long-chain triglycerides (MLCTs).
results_summary: The study found that diets enriched with pure MCTs significantly reduced weight and improved glucolipid metabolism compared to long-chain fatty acids (LCTs), while MLCTs did not show significant weight loss effects. MCTs also lowered blood triglyceride levels and insulin resistance (HOMA-IR) scores.
population_specificity: Individuals with overweight and obesity, particularly those with dyslipidemia and impaired glucose metabolism.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effectiveness of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) as a symptomatic treatment for Alzheimer's disease (AD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI) by assessing their ketogenic properties and impact on brain metabolism.
results_summary: MCT supplementation increased plasma ketone levels and brain metabolic rates, but cognitive improvements were only occasional or domain-specific. The evidence was weakened by heterogeneous study designs, bias, and conflicts of interest, making clinical benefits inconsistent.
population_specificity: Patients with Alzheimer's disease (AD) and mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA) could inhibit neurocyte apoptosis and improve cognitive function in aging mice.
results_summary: The study found that MCTs combined with DHA supplementation increased serum levels of octanoic acid (C8:0), decanoic acid (C10:0), and DHA, inhibited neurocyte apoptosis, improved neurocyte damage, and delayed age-related cognitive decline in SAMP8 mice. The combination was significantly more effective than MCTs or DHA alone.
population_specificity: Senescence-accelerated mouse-prone 8 (SAMP8) mice, a model for aging-related cognitive decline.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of nutritional counselling using MCT formulas and proper supplementation on the nutritional status, growth, and vitamin D levels of infants with biliary atresia who underwent Kasai portoenterostomy.
results_summary: Nutritional counselling with MCT-containing formulas and supplements significantly improved weight, triceps skinfold thickness, mid-upper arm circumference, and height velocity Z-scores over 3-6 months. Vitamin D levels also increased significantly in patients with improved cholestasis.
population_specificity: 36 infants with biliary atresia who underwent Kasai portoenterostomy (only 22 compliant patients were followed up).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to examine the effects and mechanisms of three distinct medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) on glucose metabolism in obese rats.
results_summary: The study found that MCTs (caprylic triglyceride, capric triglyceride, and lauric triglyceride) improved lipid and glucose metabolism, reduced insulin resistance, and lowered inflammatory markers in obese rats, with capric triglyceride showing the most significant benefits.
population_specificity: Obese Sprague-Dawley rats induced by a high-fat diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether supplementation with medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) could attenuate non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD) in obese and insulin-resistant mice.
results_summary: MCT supplementation improved glucose and insulin tolerance, reduced hepatic steatosis, lowered liver enzymes, decreased inflammation-related gene expression, and reduced hepatic ceramide and diacylglycerol content in obese mice.
population_specificity: Obese and insulin-resistant C57BL/6 male mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (MCTs contained a mixture of C8 and C10 in a 60/40 ratio).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) supplementation could increase muscle mass and function in frail older adults compared to long-chain triglycerides (LCTs).
results_summary: MCT supplementation (6 g/day) for 3 months significantly increased muscle mass (e.g., body weight, arm muscle area) and function (e.g., grip strength, walking speed) compared to LCT supplementation, with notable improvements in multiple physical performance metrics.
population_specificity: Frail older adults (mean age 85 years).
effective_dosage: 6 g/day of MCTs (C8:0 and C10:0) at dinner.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the pharmacokinetics of MCTs and their metabolites, including blood ketone bodies and breath acetone, to determine the amounts needed to induce ketogenic effects and assess the usefulness of breath acetone monitoring.
results_summary: The study found that MCTs increased total blood ketone bodies, β-hydroxybutyrate, octanoic acid, and decanoic acid in a dose-dependent manner, with a strong positive correlation between total serum ketone bodies and breath acetone, suggesting breath acetone monitoring as a less invasive method to predict ketone body concentrations.
population_specificity: 24 healthy subjects under fasting conditions
effective_dosage: Single oral doses equivalent to 0, 10, 20, and 30 g of MCTs

study_goal: The researchers aimed to validate reference genes for qPCR experiments in rat brains under mild ketosis induced by medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) and intermittent fasting, to ensure accurate mRNA expression analysis.
results_summary: The study found that reference gene stability varied by brain region, with Ppia, Actb, and Rpl13a being most stable in the medial prefrontal cortex, while B2m was invalid in the ventral hippocampus. MCT supplementation led to upregulated Gapdh and downregulated Sdha mRNA in the medial prefrontal cortex.
population_specificity: Adult Wistar rats
effective_dosage: 2 ml/kg orogastrically during 6 hours of fasting

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a diet containing medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) could protect the intestinal mucosa from chemotherapy-induced toxicity without impairing anti-tumor efficacy.
results_summary: The test diet significantly reduced gastrointestinal mucositis, diarrhea, weight loss, and maintained body composition while not impairing the anti-tumor effects of methotrexate. It also positively impacted gut microbiota diversity and resilience.
population_specificity: Tumor-naïve and tumor-bearing models (mammary adenocarcinoma) treated with methotrexate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effects of medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) supplementation on memory function in older adults without cognitive impairment.
results_summary: MCT supplementation was associated with improved memory function in 4 out of 6 studies, particularly working memory, with potential benefits more pronounced in individuals with lower baseline scores. A meta-analysis was not conducted due to the limited number of studies.
population_specificity: Older adults without cognitive impairment

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with anaplerotic and ketogenic fatty acids (including medium-chain triglycerides) could enhance fatty acid oxidation and modify acetyl-CoA metabolism via TCA cycle activity under PPARα stimulation.
results_summary: The study found that certain medium-chain triglycerides (T2M and TC5) increased fatty acid oxidation compared to controls, with TC5 showing the highest effect under clofibrate stimulation. Carnitine availability was identified as critical for maintaining fatty acid oxidation, but the hepatic oxidative capacity induced by PPARα was not significantly impacted.
population_specificity: Suckling newborn piglets (n=54)
effective_dosage: 5% of dietary formula (SUC, T2M, TC5, or TC6) with or without 0.35% clofibrate (wt/wt, dry matter basis)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to study the effects of different doses of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) on growth performance, immune and oxidative functions, and intestinal health in weaned rabbits.
results_summary: The study found that MCT at 2400 mg/kg significantly improved survival rate, fat digestibility, and serum immune and antioxidant markers, while 1800 mg/kg enhanced intestinal villus height and crypt depth. Both 1800 and 2400 mg/kg MCT increased the abundance of beneficial Bacteroidetes.
population_specificity: Weaned rabbits (35 days old, ~993.26 g initial weight)
effective_dosage: 600, 1200, 1800, and 2400 mg/kg MCT substituted for soybean oil in the diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) could improve immune status and alter gut microbiota in tunnel workers exposed to adverse environmental factors.
results_summary: MCT significantly reduced diarrhea incidence, lowered pro-inflammatory cytokines (TNF-α, CRP, IL-6), increased anti-inflammatory cytokines (IL-10, C3, C4, IgA, IgG, IgM), and altered gut microbiota composition by reducing Bacteroides and increasing Blautia and Fusicatenibacter.
population_specificity: Tunnel workers exposed to adverse environmental conditions.
effective_dosage: Not specified (MCT-milk used, exact dosage not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the procognitive effects of MCT supplementation without carbohydrate restriction and explore the underlying mechanisms linked to MCT metabolites.
results_summary: MCT supplementation benefits individuals with normal cognition and those with mild cognitive impairment or Alzheimer's disease, primarily through ketogenesis, though direct effects of MCFAs in the brain are also possible. The study highlights the need for further research on metabolic effects at higher doses (>1 g/kg).
population_specificity: Individuals with normal cognition and those with mild cognitive impairment or Alzheimer's disease.
effective_dosage: Doses larger than 1 g/kg mentioned, but specific dosage not detailed.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the historical development, physiological effects, and applied research of Medium-chain Triglycerides (MCTs) in various health contexts, including lipid absorption disorders, malnutrition, fat oxidation, protein metabolism, and cognitive function.
results_summary: The study found that MCTs have diverse physiological effects, including enhancing fat oxidation, promoting protein anabolism, and potential benefits for cognitive function in dementia patients. They are also used in ketone diets for epilepsy and nutritional support for cancer patients.
population_specificity: Healthy subjects, elderly (frailty prevention), patients with intractable epilepsy, terminally ill cancer patients, and individuals with dementia or mild cognitive impairment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine a standardized optimal amount of ketogenic formulas (KF) containing Medium-chain Triglycerides to enhance blood ketone bodies under ketogenic diet conditions.
results_summary: The study found that KF significantly increased blood ketone bodies (AcAc and BHB) after meals on the 4th day of administration, with no significant safety issues reported. Additionally, KF led to changes in gut microbiota, specifically a decrease in Firmicutes.
population_specificity: 20 healthy individuals

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of MCT supplementation on cognitive and gait functions, brain glucose metabolism, and functional connectivity in healthy older adults.
results_summary: MCT supplementation improved balance ability and suppressed glucose metabolism in the right sensorimotor cortex, which was linked to enhanced functional connectivity from the ipsilateral cerebellar hemisphere. No significant improvements were observed in cognitive or other gait parameters.
population_specificity: Healthy, normal older adults (females and males).
effective_dosage: 18 g/day (6 g/pack, ingested three times a day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the timing of MCT supplementation (breakfast vs. dinner) affects muscle function and cognition in frail elderly adults.
results_summary: MCT supplementation at either breakfast or dinner increased muscle mass, strength, function, and cognition, with no statistically significant differences between the two timing groups.
population_specificity: Frail elderly nursing home residents (average age 85.9 ± 7.7 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a ketogenic diet with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT-KD) could improve muscle strength and regeneration in genetically mutated DMD model rats.
results_summary: The MCT-KD significantly increased muscle strength and fiber diameter, suppressed muscle necrosis, inflammation, and fibrosis, and promoted satellite cell proliferation in DMD model rats. Muscle strength improvements persisted even at 9 months of age.
population_specificity: Genetically mutated DMD model rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the acceptability, tolerability, compliance, and potential seizure-reducing effects of K.Vita, a medical food containing medium-chain triglycerides (decanoic acid and octanoic acid), in individuals with drug-resistant epilepsy.
results_summary: K.Vita was well accepted and tolerated, with gastrointestinal disturbances being the primary side effect. The intervention led to a 50% reduction in mean seizure frequency, correlating with blood concentrations of medium-chain fatty acids but not ketosis.
population_specificity: Adults and children aged 3-18 years with drug-resistant epilepsy.
effective_dosage: Adults: 240 ml daily; Children: 120 ml daily (19% of daily energy).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) and caffeine on ketogenesis, comparing different MCT types and coconut oil.
results_summary: Caffeine increased ßHB levels, with C8 showing the highest ketogenic effect. All interventions led to increased hunger and reduced satiety, with mild side effects reported.
population_specificity: Seven young healthy subjects.
effective_dosage: 10 mL of tricaprylin (C8), tricaprin (C10), C8/C10 (50% C8, 50% C10), or coconut oil with or without 150 mg of caffeine.
study_duration: Ten interventions, with measurements taken over 4 hours per intervention.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) as an adjunct therapy for epilepsy by providing auxiliary brain energy and reducing seizure frequency.
results_summary: The study found that MCTs, particularly decanoic acid, show promise in reducing seizures in rodent models, dogs, and humans with epilepsy, with 65% tolerance in humans and efficacy in 50% of cases. MCTs may also have anticonvulsant, metabolic, and antioxidant mechanisms.
population_specificity: Humans and dogs with epilepsy, particularly those with certain types of epilepsy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) supplementation in reducing symptoms of Alzheimer's disease (AD) by increasing ketone body levels without drastic dietary changes.
results_summary: The study found that MCT supplementation increased ketone body levels in the blood and reduced AD symptoms in older individuals, offering a potential dietary intervention without requiring strict ketogenic diet adherence. However, the clinical studies were limited in duration and sample size.
population_specificity: Older individuals with Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the short-term effects of MCT-oil supplementation on cognitive abilities in dogs with epilepsy.
results_summary: MCT-oil supplementation significantly improved spatial-working memory, problem-solving ability, and owner-reported trainability compared to the control. The study suggests MCT supplementation may help address cognitive impairments associated with epilepsy.
population_specificity: Dogs with epilepsy (n=29, with 18 completing cognitive testing).
effective_dosage: 9% of total caloric intake as MCT oil.
study_duration: 3 months per dietary phase (6 months total with cross-over).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether adding a medium-chain triglyceride emulsion to a modified Atkins diet was feasible and well-tolerated for targeting catamenial seizures in women with epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found high adherence (81.2%) and acceptable tolerability for the medium-chain triglyceride emulsion, though side effects like abdominal pain, diarrhea, and nausea were reported. The intervention showed feasibility for future studies on ketogenic diet-based treatments for catamenial seizures.
population_specificity: Premenopausal women with epilepsy (aged 20-50 years) exhibiting a catamenial seizure pattern.
effective_dosage: Betaquik® consumed for 10 days each menstrual cycle, starting 2 days prior to and encompassing the primary catamenial seizure pattern.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the metabolic fates of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) in healthy individuals, specifically how MCT is oxidized and whether it undergoes elongation to long-chain fatty acids (LCFA).
results_summary: The study found that 42% of administered MCT was oxidized when given as a single energy source, increasing to 62% when combined with carbohydrates and proteins. Less than 1% of the MCT was converted to LCFA, suggesting minimal elongation.
population_specificity: Three healthy males at rest.
effective_dosage: Primed continuous infusion of glyceryl tri[1,2,3,4-13C4]-octanoate with either MCT-only or MCT-mix (MCT, proteins, and carbohydrates).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of coconut oil and medium-chain fatty acids (MCFA) as an alternative therapeutic strategy for Alzheimer's disease (AD) by compensating for brain glucose hypometabolism and assessing neuroprotective effects.
results_summary: The study suggests that MCFA metabolism from coconut oil may provide ketone bodies as an alternative energy source for the AD brain, potentially compensating for glucose hypometabolism. Additionally, coconut oil's polyphenolic content may offer neuroprotective antioxidant benefits, with evidence supporting effects on cognition, amyloid-β pathogenicity, inflammation, and oxidative stress.
population_specificity: Alzheimer's disease patients (indirectly addressed, as the study is a review of existing evidence).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) on cognition in frail elderly individuals.
results_summary: MCT supplementation significantly increased Mini-Mental State Examination (MMSE) scores by 3.5 points after 3 months compared to baseline, while long-chain triglycerides (LCT) decreased scores. The improvement was 2.1-fold greater at 3 months than at 1.5 months but returned to baseline after discontinuation.
population_specificity: Frail elderly nursing home residents (mean age 85.5 ± 6.8 years, BMI 18.6 ± 2.5 kg/m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Medium-chain Triglycerides (MCT) supplementation improves insulin sensitivity and beta cell function in humans.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in insulin sensitivity, beta cell function, or other metabolic parameters after 6 weeks of MCT supplementation, though there was a wide range of individual responses. Adiponectin levels decreased significantly, but other markers remained stable.
population_specificity: 22 non-diabetic adults (8 males, 14 females, mean age 39±2.9 years, baseline BMI 27.0±1.4 kg/m2).
effective_dosage: 30 grams of MCT per 2000 kcal daily, replacing part of dietary fat.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the impact of adding varying amounts of MCTs to coffee on blood levels of D-BHB and markers of oxidative stress.
results_summary: All treatments increased D-BHB, HDL-c, and TC while decreasing TAG, MDA, H2O2, and insulin. However, 42 g of MCT caused significantly greater oxidative stress compared to 28 g or no MCT.
population_specificity: Ten college-aged men.
effective_dosage: 0 g, 28 g, and 42 g of MCT in coffee.
study_duration: Acute ingestion (blood samples taken pre-, 2 h, and 4 h postprandial).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) on cognitive ability in patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease (AD) and explore changes in peripheral blood metabolomics.
results_summary: MCT significantly improved cognitive ability (measured by ADAS-Cog-C scores) in APOE4-/- AD patients compared to placebo, with notable changes in plasma metabolites, including increased ketone bodies and altered lysophosphatidylcholine levels. No significant difference was observed in self-care (ADL scores).
population_specificity: 53 mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease patients, with analysis focused on 46 APOE4-/- subjects.
effective_dosage: 17.3 g MCT daily, divided into three doses (as jelly).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MCTs alone could increase muscle strength, function, and activities of daily living (ADL) in frail elderly individuals, compared to combined supplementation or a negative control.
results_summary: MCT supplementation (6 g/d) significantly improved leg strength, swallowing function, and ADL scores in frail elderly individuals compared to the negative control group (LCT). The effects were statistically significant and clinically meaningful.
population_specificity: Frail elderly nursing home residents (mean age 85.5 ± 6.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) alone and in combination with intravenous acyl ghrelin on ghrelin levels and aerobic capacity in underweight COPD patients.
results_summary: Five-day MCT treatment increased endogenous acyl ghrelin levels, while the combination of MCT and ghrelin improved peak oxygen uptake, likely due to enhanced cardiac function and oxygen delivery. The study suggests MCT may improve aerobic capacity in underweight COPD patients through cardiocirculatory and muscular mechanisms.
population_specificity: Severe and very severe chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) patients who were underweight.
effective_dosage: Not specified (edible MCT for 5 days, followed by MCT with intravenous acyl ghrelin for 3 weeks).
study_duration: 5 days for MCT alone; 3 weeks for MCT-ghrelin combination.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combining aerobic exercise with MCT supplementation increased plasma ketone levels more than either intervention alone and whether the response differed between normoglycemic and prediabetic older women.
results_summary: MCT combined with aerobic exercise (MCT+AE) produced the highest plasma ketone levels in normoglycemic women, showing a synergistic effect. In prediabetic women, MCT alone and MCT+AE both increased ketone levels significantly compared to control or AE alone, but no synergistic effect was observed.
population_specificity: Older women (normoglycemic, n=10; prediabetic, n=9)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the safety, tolerability, and feasibility of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) versus triheptanoin as add-on treatments for adults with treatment-refractory epilepsy.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in safety, adherence, or seizure frequency reduction between MCTs and triheptanoin, though MCTs showed a protective effect on focal unaware seizures in a subset of participants. Gastrointestinal disturbances were the most common adverse events.
population_specificity: Adults with treatment-refractory epilepsy.
effective_dosage: Maximum of 100 mL/day, distributed over 3 meals (median doses: 59 mL/day for MCTs, 55 mL/day for triheptanoin).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether emulsified MCTs (MCT-Es) would improve ketogenesis and reduce gastrointestinal side effects compared to nonemulsified MCTs (MCT-NEs) in healthy adults.
results_summary: MCT-Es increased plasma ketones by 2- to 4-fold in a dose-dependent manner and improved MCFA bioavailability while reducing side effects by ~50% compared to MCT-NEs. MCT-NEs increased ketogenesis by 2-fold but showed no significant dose-dependent effects.
population_specificity: 10 healthy adults
effective_dosage: 10, 20, or 30 g of MCT-NEs or MCT-Es administered once with a standard breakfast
study_duration: Single-day intervention with blood sampling over 4 hours

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) reduces Candida colonization in preterm infants.
results_summary: MCT supplementation significantly reduced fungal burden during the supplementation period compared to the period before supplementation, with a rebound increase after stopping. No such changes were observed in the control group.
population_specificity: Preterm infants with Candida colonization receiving enteral feedings (either infant formula or breast milk).
study_duration: 1 week of supplementation during a 3-week study period

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) supplement therapy with a low-carbohydrate formula in treating hyperammonemic encephalopathy and improving ammonia detoxification in patients with adult-onset type II citrullinemia (CTLN2).
results_summary: MCT supplement therapy improved patients' general condition, reduced blood ammonia levels, and enhanced ammonia detoxification. Histological improvements in hepatic steatosis and ASS1-expression were observed after long-term treatment.
population_specificity: Six patients with adult-onset type II citrullinemia (CTLN2).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether brain ketone uptake in Alzheimer's disease patients increases in response to medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) supplementation, similar to young healthy adults.
results_summary: Brain ketone consumption doubled with both MCT supplements, and the relationship between plasma ketones and brain uptake matched that of healthy young adults. MCTs increased total brain energy metabolism by boosting ketone supply without affecting glucose utilization.
population_specificity: Mild-moderate Alzheimer's disease patients (n = 11 for the first MCT, n = 6 for the second).
effective_dosage: 30 g/day (first MCT: 55% caprylic acid, 35% capric acid; second MCT: 95% tricaprylin).
study_duration: One month per MCT intervention, with a wash-out period in between.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined supplementation of MCTs, L-leucine-rich amino acids, and cholecalciferol improves cognitive function in frail elderly individuals.
results_summary: The study found that the LD+MCT group showed significant improvements in cognitive function (10.6% increase in MMSE score and 30.6% increase in NM scale score), while the LD+LCT and control groups showed declines.
population_specificity: Frail elderly nursing home residents (mean age 86.6±4.8 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of LCT and MCT/LCT lipid emulsions in TPN on nutritional status and survival time in patients with refractory cachexia.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in nutritional status changes between LCT and MCT/LCT groups during short-term TPN. Survival time after surgical gastrostomy was highly variable, with a median of 98 days.
population_specificity: 50 patients (23 female, 27 male, median age 66) with refractory cachexia due to dysphagia from solid tumors obstructing the gastrointestinal tract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) on intestinal morphology, function, and energy metabolism in piglets with intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR).
results_summary: MCT treatment improved intestinal morphology, digestion, and absorption functions in IUGR piglets, while also enhancing energy metabolism markers such as ATP concentrations and enzyme activity. The study demonstrated that MCT alleviated IUGR-induced intestinal damage and metabolic inefficiencies.
population_specificity: Piglets with intrauterine growth retardation (IUGR) and normal birth weight (NBW) piglets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MCT supplementation could ameliorate ventricular remodeling in spontaneously hypertensive rats by modulating myocardial fatty acid metabolism.
results_summary: MCT supplementation stimulated fatty acid oxidation, reduced hypertrophy and oxidative stress, and maintained energy levels without affecting blood pressure, body weight, or lipid profile.
population_specificity: Spontaneously hypertensive rats (SHRs) aged 2 months and 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the sex-specific effects of long-term MCT supplementation on lipid metabolism and metabolic syndrome in mice with VLCAD deficiency.
results_summary: Long-term MCT supplementation altered glucose homeostasis and induced severe metabolic syndrome (insulin resistance, dyslipidemia, hepatic and visceral steatosis) in female VLCAD-deficient mice, while males showed milder insulin resistance. The highly saturated MCT diet decreased hepatic SCD1 activity in females, worsening metabolic effects.
population_specificity: VLCAD-deficient mice (both sexes)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary supplementation with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) and cysteamine hydrochloride (CSH) could stimulate the somatotropic axis to improve growth and performance in pigs.
results_summary: MCT supplementation increased growth hormone (GH) and ghrelin levels, reduced scouring, maintained intestinal villous height, and stabilized weight gain in weaner pigs. However, in grower-finisher pigs, MCT did not affect weight gain or feed conversion despite increasing endocrine markers.
population_specificity: Young and growing pigs (weaner, grower-finisher, and female pigs of ~60 kg).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 8-carbon (MCT8) and 10-carbon (MCT10) medium-chain triglycerides improve cognition and synaptic stability in aged rats, independent of ketone production.
results_summary: MCT10 improved novel object recognition memory, while both MCT8 and MCT10 enhanced social recognition. Both MCT diets influenced synaptic stability and protein synthesis markers, with MCT10 showing additional effects on Akt phosphorylation. Brain ketone levels were unaffected.
population_specificity: 21-month-old Wistar rats (aged rodent model).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a ketogenic diet rich in omega-3 fatty acids and medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) could delay tumor growth in a mouse xenograft model of colon cancer.
results_summary: The study found that tumor growth was significantly delayed in mice fed either the MCT-rich ketogenic diet (MKD) or the lard-based ketogenic diet (LKD) compared to those on a standard diet (SD). The results suggest that ketogenic diets, including those with MCT, may have anti-tumor effects.
population_specificity: Male BALB/C nude mice injected with HCT116 colon cancer cells.
study_duration: Until target tumor volume (600–700 mm³) was reached.
