study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether replacing long-chain triglycerides (LCTs) with medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs), specifically C8:0 and C10:0, could lead to weight loss and improved body composition in adults.
results_summary: The study found that MCTs modestly reduced body weight, waist and hip circumference, total body fat, subcutaneous fat, and visceral fat compared to LCTs, with no adverse effects on blood lipid levels. However, the results were limited by variability in study designs and potential commercial bias.
population_specificity: Healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) on growth performance, nutrient digestibility, plasma metabolites, and antioxidant capacity in weanling pigs.
results_summary: MCTs improved average daily gain, feed efficiency, nutrient digestibility, and antioxidant capacity in weanling pigs, with the most significant effects observed in the MCT2 and MCT3 groups.
population_specificity: Weanling pigs (Duroc × Landrace × Yorkshire), aged 21 ± 1 days, weighing 7.50 ± 0.28 kg.
effective_dosage: 0.7% MCTs (MCT1), 1.4% MCTs (MCT2), and 2.1% MCTs (MCT3) in the diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether Medium-chain Triglycerides (MCTs) could improve cognition in Alzheimer's disease patients by providing an alternative energy source for neurons.
results_summary: MCTs improved cognition in mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease patients who were apolipoprotein E4-negative, with mild gastrointestinal adverse events reported. The role of MCTs in clinical practice remains limited due to the lack of routine genomic profiling in Alzheimer's patients.
population_specificity: Patients with mild to moderate Alzheimer's disease, specifically apolipoprotein E4-negative individuals.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if adding medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) to a fish oil-based diet could reduce inflammatory response in mice while supporting normal growth and development.
results_summary: MCT diets reduced inflammatory markers (IL-6 and TNF-α) in response to endotoxin challenge, and combining MCT with purified fish oil (PFO) mitigated PFO's pro-inflammatory effects. All groups showed normal growth.
population_specificity: Adult male C57/Bl6 mice

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the diagnostic approach and therapeutic efficacy of a low-fat and medium-chain triglyceride diet in treating primary intestinal lymphangiectasia.
results_summary: The study found that a low-fat and medium-chain triglyceride diet, following initial total parenteral nutrition, completely relieved symptoms in a patient with protein-losing enteropathy caused by intestinal lymphangiectasia. The diagnosis was confirmed via double-balloon enteroscopy and biopsy.
population_specificity: A 17-year-old girl of Mongoloid ethnicity with primary intestinal lymphangiectasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if replacing corn oil with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) in the diet could reduce hepatic steatosis and liver injury in a rat model of non-alcoholic fatty liver disease (NAFLD).
results_summary: Increasing MCT-enriched saturated fat in the diet reduced hepatic steatosis and necrosis dose-dependently, lowered harmful fatty acid concentrations, and improved mitochondrial respiration without affecting CYP2E1 induction. MCT also reduced liver lipid susceptibility to radical attack and stimulated fatty acid oxidation via PPARα activation.
population_specificity: Male rats overfed with high-fat diets.
effective_dosage: Diets contained 10%, 35%, or 70% total energy as corn oil or a 70% fat diet with MCT-enriched saturated fat (18:82 beef tallow:MCT oil) at 20% to 65% replacement.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if dietary MCT, fish oil, and L-carnitine could counteract age-related changes in serum fatty acids and carnitine metabolites in dogs.
results_summary: The study found that MCT, fish oil, and L-carnitine supplementation attenuated age-related declines in serum carnitine metabolites and altered fatty acid profiles, including increased PUFA to SFA ratios and dose-dependent increases in beneficial fatty acids like EPA and DHA.
population_specificity: Healthy Beagles (mean age 9.9 years, range 3.1–14.8).
effective_dosage: Treatment food 2 contained increased MCT from coconut oil (exact dosage not specified).

study_goal: To evaluate the safety of medium-chain triglycerides as a potential intraocular tamponading agent for treating retinal detachments.
results_summary: The study found no retinal toxicity from medium-chain triglycerides, with only minor emulsification and inflammatory reactions observed. Cataracts developed in two cases due to perioperative trauma, not the agent itself.
population_specificity: 28 rabbits undergoing pars plana vitrectomy in the right eye.
study_duration: Up to 90 days (follow-up at days 7, 30, 60, and 90)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the influence of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) on satiety, body composition, and energy expenditure to assess its potential as a tool for weight control.
results_summary: Among 14 reviewed studies, six showed a decrease in body mass, one demonstrated a positive effect on satiation, and four reported an increase in energy expenditure. The results were inconclusive, indicating a need for further controlled studies with standardized MCT amounts.
population_specificity: Not specified (general population with potential obesity-related concerns, inferred from context).
study_duration: Varied (short and long-term interventions, exact durations not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) and N-3 fatty acids on chemically induced colitis in rats.
results_summary: The MCT+ diet (enriched with both MCTs and N-3 fatty acids) significantly attenuated proinflammatory cytokines and chemokines, reduced myeloperoxidase activity, and improved colitis severity compared to control and MCT- diets.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with chemically induced colitis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the long-term effects of MCT supplementation on abdominal fat distribution, liver fat, and metabolic health in mice with VLCAD deficiency.
results_summary: Long-term MCT supplementation in VLCAD-deficient mice led to significant visceral fat accumulation, increased serum free fatty acids, reduced polyunsaturated fatty acids, liver fat accumulation, and oxidative stress, resembling metabolic syndrome and nonalcoholic steatohepatitis.
population_specificity: Mice with very-long-chain acyl-coenzyme A dehydrogenase deficiency (VLCAD(-/-)).
effective_dosage: Not specified (MCTs replaced long-chain triglycerides without increasing total fat content).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a lipid emulsion containing MCTs and soybean, olive, and fish oils was as safe and well tolerated as a soybean oil emulsion while improving the fatty acid profile in preterm neonates.
results_summary: The MCT-based emulsion was safe and well tolerated, with similar triglyceride levels to the control group. It significantly improved the fatty acid profile, increasing eicosapentaenoic and docosahexaenoic acids and lowering the n-6/n-3 ratio, while also reducing bilirubin levels more than the control.
population_specificity: Preterm neonates (<34 weeks' gestation) requiring parenteral nutrition.
effective_dosage: 1.0 g fat/kg BW/d (days 1-3), 2 g/kg BW/d (day 4), 3 g/kg BW/d (day 5), 3.5 g/kg BW/d (days 6-14).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the effects of different fatty acid compositions, including medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs), on calf growth, insulin response, and body composition.
results_summary: Calves fed MCTs (CAP oil) showed a greater decrease in plasma glucose after an insulin challenge compared to controls, but had lower empty body gains. Coconut oil (CCO) increased liver fat and carcass lipid accumulation despite cold stress conditions.
population_specificity: Thirty-six calves in a randomized block design.
effective_dosage: Diets delivered 32% of fatty acids as MCTs (CAP oil or CCO).
study_duration: From day 1 to harvest (approximately until 88 kg body weight).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of long-term MCT supplementation on hepatic lipid metabolism in a murine model of VLCADD, comparing it to short-term MCT-bolus administration.
results_summary: The study found that a long-term MCT diet induced severe hepatic steatosis, elevated serum free fatty acids, and impaired hepatic lipid mobilization in VLCAD-KO mice, while short-term MCT-bolus appeared safer. MCT also upregulated hepatic lipogenic genes, suggesting potential risks with prolonged use.
population_specificity: VLCAD-knockout (KO) mice and wild-type (WT) mice.
effective_dosage: Not specified (MCT diet and MCT-bolus, exact amounts not detailed).
study_duration: 5 weeks for both MCT and LCT diets.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of a novel lipid emulsion (SMOFlipid 20%) containing medium-chain triglycerides compared to a conventional soybean oil-based emulsion in premature infants.
results_summary: SMOFlipid was safe and well-tolerated, with no significant differences in adverse events or clinical parameters between groups. It showed potential benefits in reducing cholestasis markers, increasing n-3 fatty acids, and improving vitamin E status compared to the control.
population_specificity: Premature neonates (gestational age ≤ 34 weeks, birth weights 1000-2500 g, age 3-7 days).
effective_dosage: Started at 0.5 g/kg/day, increased stepwise by 0.5 g/kg/day up to 2 g/kg/day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether dietary medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) could mitigate experimental colitis in rats and influence inflammatory responses in macrophages.
results_summary: Dietary MCTs reduced TLR-4 protein levels, attenuated inflammatory cytokines (IL-1beta, TNF-alpha, MIP-2), lowered MPO activity, and improved colitis severity compared to controls. MCTs also suppressed TNF-alpha production in macrophages.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats and RAW264.7 macrophages.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if a diet enriched with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) could improve metabolic control and growth in patients with glycogen storage disease (GSD) 1.
results_summary: The MCT diet reduced uric acid concentrations in all patients and improved growth in prepubertal patients, while triglyceride levels decreased only in the youngest patient. No clinical or biochemical side-effects were observed.
population_specificity: One adult female, a 1.6-year-old boy with GSD 1a, and a 6.5-year-old girl with GSD 1b.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a topical formulation containing medium-chain triglycerides and other components could accelerate wound healing in experimental cutaneous ulcers in rats.
results_summary: The test preparation did not significantly accelerate wound healing compared to the control or reference groups, with similar repair rates and healed areas observed across all groups by day 12.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with experimentally induced cutaneous ulcers.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a new omega-3 fatty acid and medium-chain triglyceride-rich formula diet in rapidly reducing plasma triglyceride levels in patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia.
results_summary: The formula diet significantly reduced plasma triglyceride levels (from 1,601 to 554 mg/dl) and total cholesterol levels (from 417 to 287 mg/dl) within 7 days, with slight decreases in fasting glucose and uric acid levels. The treatment was well-tolerated and accepted by patients.
population_specificity: Thirty-two patients with severe hypertriglyceridemia.
effective_dosage: Not specified (formula diet composition details not provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic effectiveness of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) in managing symptoms and reducing mortality in patients with primary intestinal lymphangiectasia.
results_summary: The study found that 63% of patients treated with MCT had complete resolution of symptoms compared to 35.7% in the non-MCT group, and mortality was lower in the MCT group (3.7% vs. 17.85%). The MCT diet improved symptoms and reduced mortality but was not curative in all cases.
population_specificity: Pediatric and adult patients with primary intestinal lymphangiectasia.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether enteral nutrition supplementation, including medium-chain triglycerides (MCT), improved recovery and reduced hospital stay in patients with acute cholecystitis during the convalescent stage.
results_summary: The study found that patients receiving MCT supplementation had significantly shorter hospital stays (20.1 vs. 35.4 days) and faster recovery of activities of daily living (10.9 vs. 13.1 days) compared to the non-MCT group.
population_specificity: Patients with acute cholecystitis, categorized into poor or fair nutritional status groups.
study_duration: Duration of convalescent stage (exact length not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether replacing dietary long-chain triglycerides (LCT) with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) could mitigate alcohol-induced mitochondrial CYP2E1 induction, oxidative stress, and liver injury.
results_summary: The study found that replacing all dietary fat with MCT (32% of calories) significantly reduced mitochondrial and microsomal CYP2E1 levels, oxidative stress (4-HNE), and restored mitochondrial glutathione (GSH) levels, while also decreasing liver steatosis and inflammation. A partial replacement (16% MCT) was ineffective.
population_specificity: Rats fed alcohol-containing Lieber-DeCarli liquid diets.
effective_dosage: 16% or 32% of total calories as MCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether substituting medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) for dietary long-chain fatty acids could improve body composition and lipid profiles in patients with HIV lipodystrophy.
results_summary: The study found that substituting MCTs for long-chain fatty acids led to a dramatic improvement in body composition (increased lean mass, decreased fat mass) and lipid profile in a patient with HIV lipodystrophy after three months.
population_specificity: A 42-year-old man with HIV lipodystrophy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of a 50:50 MCT/LCT emulsion versus a 100% LCT emulsion in improving nutritional status and reducing weaning time in COPD patients with acute respiratory failure.
results_summary: Both MCT/LCT and LCT emulsions improved nutritional parameters, but the MCT/LCT group had significantly shorter weaning time. The LCT group showed a decrease in T helper-T suppressor ratio, suggesting potential immune modulation differences.
population_specificity: 24 mechanically ventilated patients with chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and acute respiratory failure.
effective_dosage: MCT/LCT emulsion (50:50 ratio) and 100% LCT emulsion, administered as total parenteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) could stimulate hepatic fatty acid beta-oxidation compared to long-chain triglycerides (LCT) and other pharmacological agents.
results_summary: The study found that MCT did not significantly affect rates of beta-oxidation or carnitine palmitoyltransferase (CPT) activity, whereas clofibrate increased both.
population_specificity: Newborn suckling piglets
effective_dosage: Not specified for MCT (only comparative dietary inclusion)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MCT supplementation prior to exercise could improve exercise tolerance and metabolic control in children with LCHAD deficiency.
results_summary: MCT supplementation before exercise reduced steady-state heart rate, lowered cumulative long-chain 3-hydroxyacylcarnitines by 30%, and increased beta-hydroxybutyrate three-fold compared to orange juice alone, suggesting improved metabolic control. No significant changes in creatine kinase or lactate levels were observed.
population_specificity: Children with long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl-CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) and mitochondrial trifunctional protein (TFP) deficiency.
effective_dosage: 0.5 g MCT per kg lean body mass, administered once 20 min prior to exercise.
study_duration: Single administration prior to each of two 45-minute exercise tests.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the enantiomeric distribution of 2-hydroxysebacic acid (2-HS) in urine samples of premature infants fed a medium-chain triglyceride (MCT)-containing diet and compare it to patients with Zellweger syndrome.
results_summary: The study found that premature infants fed MCT exhibited a dominant excretion of 2R-HS in urine, similar to Zellweger syndrome patients, suggesting similar metabolic pathways. The enantioselective analysis provided insights for diagnosing and treating peroxisomal fatty acid oxidation disorders.
population_specificity: Nine patients with Zellweger syndrome and premature infants fed an MCT-containing diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of diets rich in medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) versus long-chain triglycerides (LCTs) on body composition, energy expenditure, fat oxidation, appetite, and energy intake in overweight men.
results_summary: The study found that MCT consumption led to greater reductions in upper body adipose tissue and a trend toward greater whole-body subcutaneous fat loss compared to LCTs. MCT intake also temporarily increased energy expenditure and fat oxidation, though these effects diminished by day 28.
population_specificity: Twenty-four healthy, overweight men with BMIs between 25 and 31 kg/m².

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a lipid emulsion containing medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) and long-chain triglycerides (LCT) versus a pure LCT emulsion on lipid and carnitine metabolism and respiratory quotient in neonates after major surgery during short-term total parenteral nutrition.
results_summary: Both lipid emulsions showed similar fatty acid patterns in plasma and adipose tissue, with no significant adverse effects. The MCT group exhibited minor changes in muscle carnitine ratios, suggesting a potential metabolic effect of MCT supplementation.
population_specificity: Neonates recovering from major surgery.
effective_dosage: Not specified (50% MCT and 50% LCT emulsion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) on energy expenditure and satiety, and their potential efficacy in treating human obesity.
results_summary: The study found that MCT increases energy expenditure, may lead to faster satiety, and could facilitate weight control when replacing long-chain triglycerides (LCT) in the diet. Animal and human trials suggest MCT has a greater satiating effect and results in less body weight gain compared to LCT.
population_specificity: Animal and human subjects (specific human population not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of HCA combined with MCT on satiety and energy intake over a 2-week supplementation period.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in satiety or energy intake between HCA, HCA+MCT, and placebo groups, despite minor body weight loss across all treatments. The combination of HCA and MCT did not enhance satiety or reduce energy intake compared to placebo.
population_specificity: 7 male and 14 female subjects, aged 43±10 years, with normal to moderately obese BMI (27.6±2.0 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 500 mg HCA and 3 g MCT daily.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 2-week supplementation with HCA alone or combined with MCT enhances satiety, fat oxidation, energy expenditure, and body weight loss compared to placebo.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in satiety, fat oxidation, 24-hour energy expenditure, or body weight loss between HCA, HCA+MCT, and placebo treatments, despite all groups experiencing some weight loss.
population_specificity: Eleven overweight male subjects (mean age 47±16 years, BMI 27.4±8.2 kg/m²).
effective_dosage: 500 mg HCA and 3 g MCT (in the combined treatment), consumed with meals and snacks.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effectiveness of total parenteral nutrition (TPN) versus oral medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) diets in treating spontaneous congenital chylothorax in neonates.
results_summary: The study found that TPN resolved chylothorax significantly faster (mean 10 days) compared to MCT (mean 23 days), though chyle loss did not differ significantly between the groups. The results suggest TPN is more effective than MCT for this condition.
population_specificity: Neonates with spontaneous congenital chylothorax (6 from the study center, 11 from literature).
study_duration: Mean duration was 10 days for TPN and 23 days for MCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) and vitamin E could reduce lipid peroxidation and reverse alcoholic liver injury in rats.
results_summary: MCTs combined with dextrose nearly normalized liver histology, reduced lipid peroxidation, and decreased cytochrome P450 2E1 activity, outperforming both the control and vitamin E groups. Vitamin E also showed moderate improvement, but MCTs were most effective in reversing liver injury.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats with induced alcoholic liver injury.
study_duration: 2 weeks (after 6 weeks of initial liver injury induction).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential advantages of Medium-chain Triglycerides (MCT) over Long-chain Triglycerides (LCT) for nutritional and metabolic support in clinical settings.
results_summary: The study found that MCT has unique physiochemical and metabolic properties theoretically advantageous over LCT, but clinical data comparing their efficacy has been equivocal. Future studies with clear outcome objectives are needed to confirm MCT's theorized metabolic superiority.
population_specificity: Patients with immunosuppression, critical illness, liver and pulmonary disease, and premature infants.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test the effects of MCT supplementation during a very low-calorie diet (VLCD) on weight loss, body composition, ketone production, and appetite regulation.
results_summary: The MCT group showed significantly greater weight loss and fat reduction during the first 2 weeks, higher ketone levels, lower nitrogen excretion, reduced hunger, and increased satiety compared to the LCT and low-fat groups, though these effects diminished by weeks 3-4.
population_specificity: Obese women with BMI >30 kg/m².
effective_dosage: 8.0 g/100 g of the VLCD product (Adinax).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if feeding medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) to sows during late gestation and early lactation would improve neonatal pig survival.
results_summary: MCT supplementation improved piglet survival rates, particularly in low-birth-weight pigs (<900 g), with survival rates of 68% in the MCT group compared to 32% in the control group. No effect was observed on average pig weight or the number of live pigs at birth.
population_specificity: Sows during late gestation and early lactation, and their neonatal piglets.
effective_dosage: 10% MCT in the diet (isoenergetic and isonitrogenous with control and LCT diets).
study_duration: From day 91 of gestation through day 7 of lactation (approximately 21 days total).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to test whether substituting medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) in the diet could improve glycemic control in ambulatory patients with non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM).
results_summary: The study found that postprandial blood glucose excursions were reduced after one month on the MCT diet compared to the long-chain triglyceride (LCT) diet, but fasting glucose, hepatic glucose output, and insulin-mediated glucose metabolism showed no improvement. The overall impact on glycemic control was minimal.
population_specificity: Five subjects with non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM).
effective_dosage: 77.5% of fat kcal substituted as MCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of different lipid compositions, including medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs), on plasma fatty acid profiles in severe head injury and cerebral stroke patients.
results_summary: Diets with MCTs (B and C) led to a less pronounced rise in linoleic acid (18:2 omega 6) compared to the soybean oil-only diet (A), with diet C also increasing dihomo-gamma-linolenic acid (20:3 omega 6) and docosapentaenoic acid (22:5 omega 3). Arachidonic acid levels remained stable across all diets.
population_specificity: Adult severe head injury and cerebral stroke patients in intensive care units.
effective_dosage: Diet B: 50% MCTs (mixed with soybean oil); Diet C: 42.5% MCTs (with soybean and blackcurrant seed oils).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) improve insulin-mediated glucose metabolism in diabetic and nondiabetic subjects.
results_summary: MCT reduced preprandial glycemic excursions by 45% in diabetic patients and increased insulin-mediated glucose disposal in both diabetic and nondiabetic subjects, though it did not alter fasting serum glucose or insulin levels. No significant adverse effects were reported.
population_specificity: 10 non-insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus (NIDDM) patients, 4 hypertriglyceridemic, and 6 normotriglyceridemic nondiabetic control subjects.
effective_dosage: 40% fat diet with 77.5% of fat calories as MCT.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the therapeutic efficacy of oral carnitine and glycine supplementation in a patient with ethylmalonic/adipic aciduria, using medium-chain triglycerides to provoke mild metabolic stress.
results_summary: The study found that medium-chain triglyceride supplementation altered urinary metabolite excretion patterns, with glycine enhancing conjugation and excretion of fatty acyl-CoA intermediates as effectively as carnitine. The results suggest glycine supplementation could be beneficial for similar metabolic disorders.
population_specificity: A 9-year-old girl with ethylmalonic/adipic aciduria.
study_duration: The intervention lasted 18 days, divided into phases with and without carnitine and glycine supplementation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the therapeutic effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) oil in a patient with familial chylomicronemia syndrome and undetectable lipoprotein lipase (LPL) activity.
results_summary: MCT oil and omega-3 fatty acid therapy normalized the patient's plasma triglycerides, with postheparin plasma LPL activity and mass improving to 24-39% of normal. Discontinuation of therapy led to a rapid increase in triglycerides, indicating the treatment's effectiveness.
population_specificity: A single patient with recurrent pancreatitis, hypertriglyceridemia, and undetectable postheparin plasma LPL mass and activity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of low-dose MCT supplementation on muscle mass, function, and fat mass in frail older adults, compared to LCT supplementation.
results_summary: MCT supplementation (6 g/day) increased muscle mass and function while decreasing fat mass, partly due to increased postprandial energy expenditure via SNS stimulation. Potential mechanisms include SNS activation, increased plasma acyl-ghrelin, and nitrogen-sparing effects of ketone bodies.
population_specificity: Frail older adults (mean age 85 years).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the utilization of medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) in pigs, examining the effects of emulsification and dosage on plasma medium-chain fatty acid (MCFA) concentrations.
results_summary: Emulsified MCT, particularly with Tween 80, significantly increased plasma MCFA concentrations compared to non-emulsified MCT or other emulsifiers. Higher dosages of MCT led to linearly increased plasma octanoate levels, but transient narcosis was observed at higher emulsified doses.
population_specificity: 24-hour-old pigs.
effective_dosage: 3, 6, 9, or 12 mL of non-emulsified MCT; 2, 4, 6, or 8 mL of emulsified MCT (30% Tween 80 emulsion).
study_duration: 4-hour feed withholding followed by a 2-hour observation period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the health benefits of functional lipids, including Medium-chain Triglycerides, in preventing and treating chronic diseases.
results_summary: Medium-chain Triglycerides were reported to have positive effects on human health, though further research is needed to clarify dosages, mechanisms of action, and long-term effects.
population_specificity: Not specified (general human health focus)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether chronic MCT supplementation could enhance cognitive performance before exercise and offset cognitive decline caused by prolonged exercise.
results_summary: MCT supplementation improved before-exercise cognitive performance and mitigated exercise-induced cognitive decline in most tasks, though some measures like working memory showed maintained post-exercise benefits. The placebo group did not exhibit these improvements.
population_specificity: Participants divided into MCT (n=9) and placebo (n=10) groups.
effective_dosage: 6 g of MCT (specific frequency not stated).
study_duration: Duration not specified in the abstract.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) versus omega-3 PUFAs on tryptophan metabolism and mental state during endurance training.
results_summary: The study found no significant changes in mood or IL-6 concentrations in the MCT group, nor any notable effects on tryptophan metabolites compared to the omega-3 group. MCT supplementation did not demonstrate significant neuroprotective or neurotoxic metabolic changes.
population_specificity: 26 male runners and 14 inactive subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if MCT oil supplementation reduces seizure frequency in adults with intractable epilepsy and assess side effects and urinary ketone presence.
results_summary: MCT oil supplementation was associated with an estimated 42% reduction in seizures. Reported side effects included mild nausea, stomachache, and loose stools.
population_specificity: Adult patients with intractable epilepsy in a U.S. neurology clinical practice.
effective_dosage: Twice daily, as tolerated (specific amount not stated).
study_duration: Three months (including 1-2 week titration and 1-2 week tapering off).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the phenotypic and genotypic spectrum of mitochondrial long-chain fatty acid oxidation and carnitine metabolism defects, including treatment outcomes involving medium-chain triglyceride (MCT) supplementation.
results_summary: Thirteen patients were treated with a long-chain fat-restricted diet and MCT supplementation, though specific efficacy outcomes for MCTs alone were not detailed. The study noted a statistically significant association between rhabdomyolysis and hypoglycemia in symptomatic patients, but MCTs' role in mitigating these effects was not explicitly analyzed.
population_specificity: Patients with mitochondrial long-chain fatty acid oxidation and carnitine metabolism defects (n=38), including VLCAD, LCHAD, CACT, MAD, CPT-I, CPT-II deficiencies, and CTD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of palmiteolate supplementation versus medium-chain triglycerides (placebo) on inflammatory biomarkers and self-reported musculoskeletal discomfort in individuals with chronic pain.
results_summary: The study found no significant correlation between baseline biomarkers and musculoskeletal discomfort levels. The crossover analysis results were not fully reported in the abstract.
population_specificity: Individuals with non-specific chronic musculoskeletal discomfort.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if an enteral formulation containing MCT and hydrolyzed peptides could minimize pancreatic stimulation by reducing CCK release and alleviate pain in chronic pancreatitis patients.
results_summary: The MCT-containing formulation significantly reduced CCK levels compared to standard formulations and high-fat meals, and it led to a 61.8% average improvement in pain scores among chronic pancreatitis patients, with clinical improvement in 6 of 8 participants.
population_specificity: Healthy controls (n=6) and chronic pancreatitis patients (n=8).
effective_dosage: Three cans per day of the enteral formulation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of ketogenic medium-chain triglycerides (kMCTs) on brain metabolism and cognitive performance in individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that consumption of a kMCT drink (BrainXpert Energy Complex) improved cognitive performance in individuals with MCI compared to placebo, as demonstrated in the 6-month BENEFIC trial. The results suggest that ketogenic supplements may serve as an effective nutritional intervention for cognitive enhancement in MCI.
population_specificity: Older individuals (above 60 years) with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a 6-month kMCT intervention on cardiometabolic markers and peripheral inflammation in individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).
results_summary: The study found that 30 g/day of kMCT significantly increased ketones, plasma 8:0 and 10:0 acids, and IL-8 levels, but had minimal effects on other cardiometabolic and inflammatory markers compared to a placebo. The results support the safety of kMCT supplementation in MCI patients.
population_specificity: Individuals with mild cognitive impairment (MCI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether formula with high MCT content (≥30% by weight) compared to low MCT content (<30% by weight) improves short-term growth in preterm infants primarily fed formula.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in short-term growth parameters (weight gain, length gain, head circumference) between high and low MCT formulas. Evidence was of very low to low certainty, and no clear benefits or adverse effects were established.
population_specificity: Preterm infants (<37 weeks' gestation) on full enteral diets, predominantly fed formula.
effective_dosage: High MCT formula defined as ≥30% by weight; low MCT formula as <30% by weight.
study_duration: Minimum of five days (exact duration varied by included studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of oligomeric enteral nutrition formulas containing medium-chain triglycerides in managing oncology treatment-related diarrhea and malnutrition.
results_summary: The study found mixed results regarding the efficacy of oligomeric enteral nutrition in improving outcomes for patients with oncology treatment-related diarrhea, with some benefits noted in oral mucositis but inconsistent results for other outcomes. The review highlighted a lack of standardized guidelines and heterogeneous findings across studies.
population_specificity: Oncological patients experiencing treatment-related diarrhea and malnutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to highlight the lack of sufficient intervention studies on Medium-chain Triglycerides (MCTs) and their potential role in preventing frailty syndrome.
results_summary: The abstract notes that evidence on the relevance of MCTs in preventing frailty is scarce, and it encourages further clinical trials to explore their effectiveness.
population_specificity: Frail elderly individuals, typically aged 65 and older.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if MCT ingestion improves cognitive function in young, healthy adults and to establish the ideal dosage and timeframe for these effects.
results_summary: MCT ingestion improved cognitive performance in tasks like Trail Making A/B and Digit Span after 2-3 weeks, with minimal difference between 12 g and 18 g/day doses. No significant effects were observed in attention or reaction time tasks.
population_specificity: Young, healthy adults

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a high-protein diet versus a high-carbohydrate diet, both supplemented with medium-chain triglycerides, on metabolic control, body composition, and liver fat in patients with long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders (LC-FAODs).
results_summary: Both diets maintained metabolic control without worsening LC-FAOD symptoms. The high-protein diet reduced liver fat and preserved lean body mass, while the high-carbohydrate diet led to lean mass loss.
population_specificity: Patients diagnosed with long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders (LC-FAODs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of medium-chain triglycerides in addressing malnutrition and improving nutritional outcomes in children with chronic liver disease.
results_summary: The study suggests that dietary intervention, including supplementation with medium-chain triglycerides, can help meet increased metabolic demands and prevent nutritional deficiencies in children with chronic liver disease. It emphasizes a multidisciplinary approach for optimal nutritional management.
population_specificity: Children with chronic liver disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-proportion MCT supplementation could mitigate glucocorticoid-induced centripetal fat distribution and alter leptin and adiponectin levels in children with ALL during chemotherapy.
results_summary: The study found that MCT supplementation prevented waist circumference increase observed in the control group by day 46 of chemotherapy, though no significant differences were noted in hip circumference, leptin/adiponectin levels, or body weight. The MCT group showed no BMI increase at discharge compared to controls, suggesting potential benefits in fat distribution.
population_specificity: New-onset ALL children treated at Guangzhou Women and Children's Medical Center.
effective_dosage: Not specified (subgroups A and B based on supplement amount, but exact doses not provided).
study_duration: Measurements taken before and on days 19 and 46 of chemotherapy; intervention duration not explicitly stated.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of RELiZORB, an in-line digestive cartridge, in hydrolyzing fats (including medium-chain triglycerides) in enteral nutrition formulas for patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency.
results_summary: RELiZORB effectively hydrolyzed over 90% of fats in most enteral formulas into absorbable fatty acids and monoglycerides, demonstrating high efficacy in fat absorption for pancreatic insufficient patients. The study highlighted its compatibility with various polymeric and semielemental formulas.
population_specificity: Patients with exocrine pancreatic insufficiency (EPI) receiving enteral nutrition.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the outcome and effects of long-term treatment with medium-chain triglycerides (MCT) in a mouse model of VLCAD-deficiency.
results_summary: The study examined the application of a single MCT bolus in VLCAD-deficient mice, suggesting potential benefits in managing metabolic derangement, but detailed results were not provided in the abstract.
population_specificity: Mouse model of VLCAD-deficiency.
effective_dosage: Single MCT bolus (specific amount not provided).

study_goal: The study aimed to determine the incidence, risk factors, and treatment strategies for chylothorax in pediatric cardiac surgery, including the use of medium-chain fatty acid supplementation.
results_summary: Medium-chain fatty acid supplementation was used in 1.7% of patients with chylothorax, but the study did not focus on its efficacy or safety, instead highlighting its inclusion in treatment strategies. The abstract does not provide detailed outcomes specific to medium-chain triglycerides.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients (under 18 years) undergoing congenital heart surgery or heart transplant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of purified palmitoleic acid supplementation against a placebo (medium-chain triglycerides) in adults with dyslipidemia and mild systemic inflammation.
results_summary: The study found no significant effects attributed to medium-chain triglycerides, as it served as the placebo control. The intervention group (palmitoleic acid) showed significant improvements in lipid profiles and inflammation markers compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Adults with dyslipidemia and mild systemic inflammation (hs-CRP between 2 and 5 mg/L).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether medium-chain triglycerides (MCTs) activate ghrelin and influence physiological changes in anorexia nervosa patients.
results_summary: The study found that higher MCT intake significantly increased ghrelin activation and neuropeptide Y (NPY) levels, suggesting MCT supplementation may aid in treating emaciated AN patients. No significant effects were observed on other measured factors.
population_specificity: Inpatients diagnosed with anorexia nervosa (AN).
effective_dosage: Three dosage groups: 'MCT high' (>6 g/day), 'MCT moderate' (1-6 g/day), and 'MCT low' (<1 g/day).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of melatonin in mitigating UV-B radiation damage in alfalfa plants and its effects on antioxidant defense and photosynthetic efficiency.
results_summary: Exogenous melatonin effectively repaired UV-B-induced damage by activating antioxidant defense and enhancing photosynthetic efficiency, while 5-hydroxytryptamine showed similar effects by increasing endogenous melatonin. Coumarin had no significant improvements.
population_specificity: Alfalfa plants (leguminous species)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether MCT supplementation prior to exercise improves substrate oxidation and reduces cardiac workload in individuals with inherited long-chain fatty acid oxidation disorders (CPT2, VLCAD, and LCHAD deficiencies).
results_summary: MCT supplementation before exercise decreased glucose oxidation and cardiac workload while increasing ketone body production, suggesting improved energy utilization and reduced metabolic strain compared to carbohydrate supplementation.
population_specificity: Individuals with carnitine palmitoyltransferase 2 (CPT2), very long-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase (VLCAD), and long-chain 3-hydroxyacyl CoA dehydrogenase (LCHAD) deficiencies.
effective_dosage: Isocaloric oral dose (specific amount not stated).
study_duration: Single dose administered prior to each 45-minute exercise session.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of paediatric prolonged-release melatonin (PedPRM) in alleviating sleep disturbances and improving PTSD symptoms, daytime functioning, and mental health in children and adolescents with PTSD.
results_summary: The study protocol describes a planned investigation into PedPRM's effects, noting its prior beneficial effects on insomnia in children with autism spectrum disorders and positive impacts on anxiety and depressive symptoms, but results from this specific trial are not yet available.
population_specificity: Children and adolescents with PTSD (120 participants).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of a treatment regimen including medium-chain triglycerides, a fat-free diet, and total parenteral nutrition, with or without octreotide, in managing chylous leaks post-liver transplant.
results_summary: The study found that combining octreotide with a fat-free diet and total parenteral nutrition (including medium-chain triglycerides) was effective in curing chylous leaks, with faster resolution (≤2 weeks) compared to diet and total parenteral nutrition alone (3-36 days).
population_specificity: A 62-year-old man with cirrhosis, hepatitis C, and hepatocellular carcinoma post-liver transplant, alongside a review of 11 major reported cases.
effective_dosage: Not specified for medium-chain triglycerides. Octreotide was administered at 100 μg subcutaneously every 8 hours.
study_duration: Varied; up to 6 weeks for some interventions, with octreotide used for 14 days in the reported case.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate melatonin's protective effects against 5-fluorouracil-induced cardiotoxicity in rats, focusing on oxidative stress, inflammation, gene expression, and histopathological changes.
results_summary: Melatonin significantly reduced oxidative stress markers, inflammatory mediators, and histopathological damage caused by 5-FU, while enhancing antioxidant activity and preserving myocardial tissue integrity in a dose-dependent manner.
population_specificity: Male Wistar rats

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how exogenous melatonin regulates phenolic compounds biosynthesis and phenylpropane metabolism during pepper ripening.
results_summary: Melatonin treatment elevated total phenolics and flavonoids in pepper fruits, upregulated genes involved in phenolic synthesis, and activated phenylpropane metabolism, improving fruit quality. Metabolomics identified 15 substances with high fold-change values, indicating enhanced phenolic compound accumulation.
population_specificity: Pepper plants (Capsicum annuum)
effective_dosage: 100 µmol·L-1, applied as a surface spray
study_duration: Applied 10 days after anthesis (exact duration of ripening not specified)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanisms by which melatonin and exercise mitigate sarcopenia-related deficits in muscle health, particularly in Bmal1-deficient mice.
results_summary: Melatonin treatment reversed sarcopenia-related deficits, including impaired muscle function, mitochondrial dysfunction, and disrupted muscle regeneration, independently of Bmal1. It also restored antioxidant defense and reduced inflammatory response in skeletal muscle.
population_specificity: Skeletal muscle-specific and inducible Bmal1 knockout mice (iMS-Bmal1-/-).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether melatonin could mitigate the immunotoxic effects of thiacloprid (THI) on lymphocytes, specifically by reducing pyroptosis and improving mitochondrial function.
results_summary: Melatonin reversed THI-induced lymphocyte pyroptosis, restored mitochondrial membrane potential, reduced mtROS levels, and improved anti-inflammatory capacity via the mtROS/cGAS-STING/NF-κB axis.
population_specificity: Lymphocytes from an unspecified source (likely common carp, based on the abstract's conclusion).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine how melatonin promotes diabetic wound healing by mediating mitochondrial function in endothelial cells via the AMPK/SIRT1/HIF-1α pathway.
results_summary: Melatonin improved cell viability, angiogenesis, and wound healing in high glucose-treated endothelial cells, reduced oxidative stress and apoptosis markers, and enhanced mitochondrial function. These effects were mediated through activation of the AMPK/SIRT1/HIF-1α pathway.
population_specificity: Human umbilical vein vascular endothelial cells (HUVECs) exposed to high glucose to mimic a diabetic environment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the protective effect of melatonin against gabapentin-induced hematotoxicity and hepatorenal toxicity in female Albino rats.
results_summary: Melatonin, when administered 12 hours before gabapentin, mostly ameliorated the altered hematological and biochemical parameters, as well as hepatic and renal histopathological architecture, restoring them to normal levels. The combination of melatonin and bee pollen also provided protection against gabapentin-induced changes.
population_specificity: Female Albino rats
